awd_titl_txt: BIGDATA: F: Critical Visualization Technologies for Analyzing and Understanding Big Network Data
awd_abstract_narration:
Big data presents both opportunities and challenges to all fields of study and practice. Visualization has been proven effective as a knowledge discovery and storytelling tool for big data. This project aims to develop new visualization technologies for big network data that will both illustrate empirical findings and generate new discoveries. Although many network visualization techniques and tools have been introduced, visualizing large, dynamic networks to extract key entities, structures, and trends from the network data remains a challenging task. Most of the existing network visualization solutions were not designed for handling dynamic networks and are too slow for interactive exploration of large networks. This project will closely examine the integral parts of a holistic solution for the problem of big network visualization.  The research study will be largely driven by the data analysis needs of sociological studies such as finding hidden associations between multiple networks; however, the project team will also investigate the solution's applicability in areas such as emergency management, life science and cyber security. The resulting technologies are expected to drastically enhance one's ability to explore and understand large, complex dynamic networks for knowledge discovery, critical decision making, and storytelling. This research effort is timely because of the explosive growth of data and common use of graphs as both the internal data structure and a visual representation in data-driven applications. Those who must deal with large, complex dynamic network data for their work will benefit from the advanced visualization technologies resulted from this research project. Students participating in this project will acquire strong interdisciplinary research skills for real-world problem solving. 

This research underscores the importance of providing a comprehensive solution to the understanding of big data containing complex relations, structure, and trends. Primary research topics are: (1) Visual depiction and exploration of big network data; (2) Modeling and visualizing dynamic network data; (3) Visual monitoring and analysis of live, streaming network data; and (4) Provenance and storytelling with dynamic network data.  This project will explore and integrate new network modeling, reduction, and visualization techniques for analyzing large, multivariate dynamic graphs. The resulting research innovations will both enhance existing methods and investigate new approaches to dynamic network visual analytics and drastically improve their usability for real-world applications. The targeted applications, emergency service and sociology, present the project team with some of the most challenging problems to address in making sense of heterogeneous dynamic big networks data. The collaborating domain experts are fully committed to participating in the evaluation work, which promises to produce usable technologies that will enable respondents to look at the data in new ways and uncover intricate relations among different entities/events for critical decision making and mitigation planning. The project results will be disseminated to the visualization community and beyond through annual conferences, workshops, and tutorials, and also through the project website which will include project status updates and resulting images, videos, and prototype software.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Relational data such as abstract trees and networks are one of the primary classes of information.  This kind of data turns up in many different disciplines, including sociology, biology, engineering, computer networks, and many more. Some of these networks are abstract, such as social influence networks. Others describe physical networks, such as power distribution networks or the router connectivity of the Internet. Analysis of these networks can lead to important insights. For example, analysis of a social network can reveal patterns about groups of friends or popularity, and analysis of a power distribution network can indicate key points for infrastructure improvements. A common and intuitive way to analyze such networks is to visually represent them as a node-link diagram, where the nodes represent entities in the network and the links drawn between nodes represent the relationship between them. While visualizing small networks in this way is relatively easy to do, larger and more complex networks are often difficult. In particular, time-varying networks become quite common in real world situations, analyzing networks that evolve over time is far more challenging, especially at large scale.

This research underscores the importance of providing comprehensive solutions to the understanding of big data containing complex relations, structure, and trends. We have introduced and integrated new network modeling, reduction, and visualization techniques for analyzing large, multivariate dynamic graphs. We have not only enhanced existing methods to drastically improve their usability for real-world applications, but also investigated new approaches such as generative modeling for fostering novel technologies, a machine learning approach to extracting and understanding unique characteristics in multivariate networks,  a multi-layout design for immersive visualization, etc. 

We have conducted substantial user studies to evaluate each of our designs and confirm its efficacy and usability.  Our research is timely because of the explosive growth of data and common use of graph as both the internal data structure and a visual representation in data-driven applications. The resulting new network visualization and analysis capabilities benefit those who must deal with large, complex dynamic network data for their work and find applications in a wide variety of areas from life science, social science to healthcare and cyber security. To broadly disseminate our research results, besides academic publications, we have made each new technology available in the form of open-source toolkits or libraries.

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2022
Modified by: Kwan-Liu Ma

Images (1 of )
  • A generative model is trained to construct a 2D latent space of network layouts by learning from a collection of example layouts
    Kwan-Liu Ma
    Copyrighted
    Kwan-Liu Ma
    Generative modeling of network layouts
  • A map of 8263 networks in layout method FM3. Each color dot is a network, and networks with similar structures are place in the same proximity of the map. Similarity computation uses Graph Kernel.
    Oh-Hyun Kwon and Kwan-Liu Ma
    Copyrighted
    Kwan-Liu Ma
    Map of networks
  • Immersive visualization of a hierarchical network using a multi-layout design. A single group is expanded, and its nodes and intra-subnetwork connectivity can be inspected in detail while preserving the inter-subnetwork context.
    David Bauer and Kwan-Liu Ma
    Copyrighted
    Kwan-Liu Ma
    Immersive visualization of network data
